Does a career focused on changing the world's energy future intrigue you? If so, we might have just the opportunity you're looking for! Idaho National Laboratory’s (INL) Mobility Systems & Analytics (MSA) group is seeking forward-thinking, professionals interested in exploring a career as an Electric Vehicle Data Scientist (EVDS)! The EVDS will provide expertise to the MSA group and harness Big Data to address some of our nation’s toughest transportation challenges. As private industry accelerates electric vehicle (EV) adoption, the researcher will help INL strengthen its leadership role within the Department of Energy's (DOE) Vehicle Technologies Office (VTO) in using data to understand EV technology, consumer behavior, charging infrastructure needs, and EV/grid integration opportunities. In this position, the researcher develops and/or uses ground breaking data analytics techniques including machine learning to draw insights from data collected from thousands of EVs and charging stations in use around the United States. You will also work with modelers to develop representative EV operating profiles and technology adoption models. The researcher plays a key role on an interdisciplinary team with operations researchers, EV and power systems specialists, and INL’s high-performance computing professionals to run and develop simulations to anticipate the impact of EV charging at scale on the electric grid. Finally, the researcher works with automotive manufacturers, electric utilities, and other key partners to ensure INL research results directly benefit efforts to provide clean, affordable, reliable energy and mobility. In this role, the researcher brings expertise in EV consumer behavior, policy, and emerging market trends to the team. The individual will be expected to collaboratively conduct work, publish results and develop proposals, with other INL scientists in EV charging, energy storage, power systems, and other fields. Additionally, the individual regularly collaborates with scientists at other national laboratories through joint research projects funded by the U.S. DOE's VTO. The researcher interacts with DOE program managers and partners to develop, present research plans, receive feedback, and share results.
